sp.l: Then since there's no Evasion,— Oroandes draws.
Witness ye Gods my Innocence is wrong'd.
But Gracious Sir,— Oroandes kneels.
sp.p: Before I fall, or stand less fortunate, to see you overthrew, Oh let me know what Fate, what Cruel Fate has Rob'd me of the Treasure of your Love.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: And must such goodness die? Know noble Youth, I am so far from calling it desert in thee, that hath unsheath'd my Sword, that in this midnight storm of fancy I can shed some drops of Pitty too. I come not rashly to attempt thy life, but long have struggled with my hot desires, stood fiery Tryals of temptations. I am diseas'd, and know no way to health but through a deluge of thy blood,— there is a cause.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Dear Sir reveal it, that e're I fall, my penitential tears may cleanse my Soul from such a Leprous Crime.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Alas brave Youth, thy thought's white as the Robes of Angels are, I know thy Love to fair Amasia inseperable, as goodness from a Deity, yet I must deprive thee of this Darling of thy Soul.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: With pardon Royal Sir, I cannot think the Cyprian Princess is so soon forgot, with whom Amasia Sir compar'd is nothing.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Darst thou affect her, yet dispraise a Beauty that in its Orb contracts Divinity? This Prophanation what had else bin sin will render Meritorious,— Guard thy Life.

div.stage: They fight, the King is wounded.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: What have I done?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The Business that we met for, now we are friends again, friends until Death. The King staggers and falls.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Oh do not faint, call up your spirits Sir, there's hopes of Life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: My Vital Powers fail, my Eyes are bowing to Eternal night.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: And I grow wild with Horror,— milder then a Flame provok'd by angry Winds; what shall I do, or whither shall I flie, to leave behind me this pursuing Guilt? A noise within.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Oh, Oh,— be gone, be gone my Oroandes, some Company draws near. Maist thou live long and happily in the Embraces of her whom I unjustly strove to have: my dying wishes wait upon your joys.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: Angels attend your latest hour, I go
From hence to meet my Everlasting woe. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Heroina, Vanlore, Shepherds, and Shepherdesses.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: I thought I heard th' unruly noise of Swords,
And Clashing Murmurs of unfriendly words,
Besides the Eccho of a hollow Groan.

sp.speaker: Van
sp.l: I heard the dismal noise, and fear th' event,
These wild Bandetties live by spoiles alone,
Run on in sin, and fear no punishment.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Oh, Oh, Oh.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: — What noise is that?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: — Some newly Slain
By these untam'd Bandetties of the Plaine.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: And here lies one breathing his latest breath,
His face is cold, and all appears like Death;
Let's Beare him off
Within for his Recovery all means I'le try,
For something prompts me, that he must not die.

div.stage: They take him up, and Exeunt. Enter Theocrine and the Shepherd, the Shepherd brings back Vanlore.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: My dearest Theocrine, in all, you prove
Your Honour great, as is your Real Love.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: My Vanlore, sure I may believe my eyes,
Or doth the suddain Joy my sense surprize;
The Cruel pleasures steal so sweetly on,
Makes me mistrust the Bliss I run upon.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Your Bliss is Real, and my Joy's Compleat,
Heav'n could not give a happiness more great.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Through doubts and fears I have attain'd my will,
But 'twas unkind to let me Languish still.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: That only cast a Cloud on the design,
That with more ease you might to Love incline.
And I to live alone retir'd with pain,
Expecting still this happiness to gain;
Which thus possest, more perfect Bliss I find,
Then in the various pleasures of the mind.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Love like the wind oft shifts and seems to cease,
As if each minute lull'd it into peace;
Sweetly it breaths upon the flowry Plaine,
And yet a moment pulls it back again.
From Calms to Storms th' unruly Gust doth rise,
And scatters all the Clouds about the Skies;
So we neglectful, now our Bliss is near,
By staying, threaten dangers we should fear:
My Lovers Anger, and my Fathers Age,
With Thunder will pursue us in his Rage.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Thou art the Loadstone, and my Soul shall be
Directed only by thy Charms and thee.
'Mongst harmless Sheep, and solitary Bowers,
We'l wast the tedious Time in pleasant Hours▪
There Love and Pleasure we'l at once possess;
Who wades through Crosses meets true Happiness. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE the Court.
div.stage: Enter Zannazarro, Glorianda, and Amasia.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: How sad a change is this! This morning was appointed for more joyful Enterviews.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: When last nights slumber rob'd our wakeful hopes of the delicious births of fancy, 'twas with fairer promises: Amasia, I fain would comfort thee, but my own griefs make me a stranger to that balmy Language.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.p: Dear Sister, thy Passions are too violent; the Messengers are not yet all return'd, nor have we seen Arratus. Enter Arratus.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: And here he comes.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: My Lord, you either come to share in Grief with us, or ease ours by some blest discovery.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: My Lord, my Son, my Daughter, and my—

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: Peace, no more, mix not theirs with a Sov'raigns loss, whose least drop of Blood is worth a Thousand Lives, speak thy intelligence.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: My Largest lies within the City walls, and there he has not yet bin heard of; is none with him?

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: Yes, Oroandes, Enter a Messenger. here comes our last hopes, speak thy success.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Not good my Lord, we've travest all the Fields that Circles lofty Erix, and yet see no beam of blest Intelligence; all we found worthy to fix an Observation on, was a place beneath the Hermits Rock all stain'd with store of Blood, and near the foot this token of our Grief. Gives a bloody Handkercher which was the Kings.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: Oh my Prophetick fears!

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.p: Our sorrows are confirm'd!

sp.speaker: Glor.
sp.p: They are in Bloody Characters!

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: I'le go and secure the Cittadel, and cry Treason.

div.stage: Exit. Arratus.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: Sorrow out-grows all my Resolves, this is an Act so full of Horror 'tis terrible to name it; but if the Force of Syracuse can scourge the Traytors,
sp.l: — We'l have
Their Heads to build a Temple o're his Grave.

div.head: SCENE the Plaines.
div.stage: Enter the King lead by two Shepherds and Heroina.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I'VE now got strength enough to render to you the fair preserver of my Life; my Spirits stir, as if they would shake off the sluggish weight of weakness.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: How much in ev'ry twinkling of the eye doth he resemble my Heroick Love. Aside.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: You'r sad sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: I have a Cause, and such a one, that did you know, your Goodness would Commiserate my wretched Fortune.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Reveal it Lady, I perhaps may be inabled then to dissipate your Griefs.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
I was resolv'd to weep away my Time in private sorrow; but discovery cannot aggravate my woe; besides I may venture to
lodge a secret, where I have found such temperate vertues. I'le only with this Question Usher in my own discovery; is Sicily your place of Birth, or not?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: It is, and Breeding both.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: I will not ask what were the Parentage, where I find Vertues plant Nobility, yet would be loath to a Plebeian breast to trust what I must now divulge.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: You may be confident I am a Gentleman, as well by Birth as Education, Lady.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: I do presume it Sir, and therefore wish of all I now remain amongst to be known unto you alone. You never had Relation to the Court?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: There was my Breeding Lady.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Near the Person of the King?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: One of his Bed-Chamber, and 'tis no boast to say, as well belov'd by him as any, there being in th' opinion of the Court, a near Resemblance of our looks.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Then sure my name is not a stranger to you, have you not heard Sir of the Cyprian Princess.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The Beautious Heroina.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: The wretched Heroina, such I'm sure is my condition in my present State.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Pardon the Child of Ignorance, my wild, and unbecoming Rudeness. Kneels.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Rise Sir, we are Companions yet; and hope we shall be till your Royal Master possess what was long since intended his. By what Disaster, I was cast upon this dreadful Precipice of Danger, as we are walking I'le Relate. Enter two Bandetties.

sp.speaker: I Ban.
sp.p: A prize, a prize, a noble prize, seize you upon that pretty Shepherdess, while I dispatch the Guardian. Draws.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: 'Tis not so quickly done, and though as yet unable to defend, hither I'le fly for Rescue. Snatches the Bandetties Sword, who is going to seize Heroina. Now I'm prepar'd to scourge your sawcy Insolence.

div.stage: Fights with the first Bandetty and wounds him, the second leaves Heroina, and offers to seize the King; Enter Vanlore and Theocrine, Vanlore Draws, and drives the second Bandetty off; the first that was wounded by the King stayes.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: This was a timely Rescue, and has by the fair Redemption of my Honour bound me to give you thanks.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I merit none; my Duty urg'd me to preserve that Life which they strove thus to Ravish. The brightest Stars that Rul'd my Fate, did light me to this blest Employment; but had all set, e're their Influence had attain'd its end, had not this Gentlemans assistance lent new Vigor to their fading Beams.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: I must confess a debt of thanks to him, which if Irregular Humanity prove no Rebel to my safety, shall be suddainly discharg'd: Let this Villain attend us to the Court, there you'l find a Prince to be intreated, when your Advocate bears Heroina's name. I can forgive, and so I hope can you, although his Crimes merit a lasting punishment.

sp.speaker: 1 Ban.
sp.p: Pardon me best of Women, and impute Kneels. my Rudeness to my Ignorance. If any Service can Extenuate Crimes of such Monstrous Growth, my Blood shall pay the forfeit of my disobedience.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Your hopes of safety prompts me to believe you: Come Sir, you and that Gentleman shall attend me to the Court.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: We are your Vassals Madam, proud to have such a Command to Usher our desires.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: And you Sir.
sp.l: There I'le compleat that cure so well begun,
And raise your fading hopes for what you've done.

div.head: SCENE a Tavern. A Table, Pen Ink and Paper in it.
div.stage: Enter Led by the Nose, Sir Jasper Sympleton by Drayner, and Sir Symon Credulous by Slywit, disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Come, come along Sir, is't not enough to kill an honourable Gentleman, but you must Lampoon him when you've done, and wound his fame in Verse.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p:
Dam-me if ever I writ a Verse in my Life, or any thing like it, alas I have no more wit then a Goose, and writing's as disagreeable
to my Nature, as Hanging: I must confess I have often had an Itching mind to Poetry, but could never obtain it.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: And what makes your name Sir, crowded on the Title Page of several Plays in splendid Characters, as if that Ostentation did proclaim thee a man of wit and merit?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: I see you are Ignorant of the English Customes; their men of Wit and Sence inclin'd to Poetry, have such a little share in the Worlds Treasure, their works and them alike go both a begging, and scarce a morning but we Easie-men (who rather then our lives would be accounted the Zanies of the Age) are troubled with their Visits, where for a Guinny we purchase the Labour of three Months, and then by our Authority, with the Acting Females (who do at upon us Gallants of the Times) the Play in our name's Acted, and by Consequence, 'cause all the World should be acquainted with our Folly (which we think Wit) some Greedy Bookseller pays dear for the Copy, and by his means 'tis Usher'd into th' World; those Dedications writ by us (small Criticks) never are honour'd by a Noble Patroness, tending to down right rayling at the Age, or finding fault perhaps with the best Poets.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: This makes you Guilty of the last Lampoon, in which you have not only abus'd him who never was a Poet, but all the Poets of the Age; and therefore if you give us not (in the behalf of our dead Friend) sufficient satisfaction, you die immediately.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: This 'tis to pretend to Poetry in a strange Country: I Gad in London, a man of Nonsence is as safe (amongst the Crue of Criticks) as in a Hollands Leaguer, for they are more given to the Spirit of Contradiction, then that of Fighting. Aside.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Come Sir, dispatch, we are in hast.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: So am I to be gone. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Swear Sir.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Swear what?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Either you did, or did not write the Verses.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: I vow to Gad, and all that, I am Innocent.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: That's but a weak Oath, and shows too must of Cowardize to gain belief, swear me a full mouth'd Oath like a true Englishman.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Then on the Vertue of a Gentleman, and Honour of Sir Symon Credulous, I am not Guilty.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Honour and Vertue are two mighty strangers to an Ignoble breast; I cannot in the least Imagine they are lodg'd in your's. Come Gentlemen, here's Pen Ink and Paper, write ev'ry Letter that we shall command you, or die in disobeying.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Was ever poor Pretended led by the Nose before? Honour begone, to save my Life I'le do it; we are ready Sir.

div.stage: Sir Jasper and Sir Symon go to the Table, and prepare to write.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Write this then,— I am a Coward.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: All the World knows that already, it needs no publication.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Write I Command you.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: I am a Coward.— Write.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: An Arrand stinking Coward.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: An Arrand stinking Coward.— Write.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: A Poetical Thief.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: Not I by Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Write I say.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: A— Write.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: And a damm'd Son of a Whore, if ever I writ these Verses.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: And a— Write.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: All this I Gad is true Gentlemen, have you done?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Not yet Sir, one word more, and I do here promise to receive into my Arms, the Lady yesterday Married, to have and to hold, for better for worse, and so forth, with a promise to make her a Jointure of Three Hundred a Year; to keep (and never to part with) her, as being a Match only fit for me— Jasper Sympleton.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Withal my heart. Jasper writes.
Now Sir Symon I think I am even with you. Aside.
Here Sir I deliver this to you as my Act and Deed.

div.stage: Gives Drayner the Paper.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: So this is well. And now Gentlemen, 'cause you shall be eas'd of all your fears and miseries, all disputations 'twixt you two must cease; the Lady, the Beautious Lady Theocrine by Nuptial tye is yours, and as your Wife receive her.

div.stage: Enter Julia.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: Withal my heart, now you have plaid the part of honest men, welcome into my Arms.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Pray Heav'n you find us so, do you know me Sir?

div.stage: Discovers himself.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: What Drayner, Servant to my Rival Sir Symon Credulous, nay then I fear the worst.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: I am the honest man you talk of Sir, and 'cause you shall not dwell in Ignorance too long, behold whom you have Married.

div.stage: Discovers Julia.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: Cheated, Gul'd, abus'd by Heav'n; have I Married this Chamber-maid?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: This Chamber-woman you have Sir, I was a Maid until you made me otherwise; and afterwards you would perswade me to have bin as false as Dunkirk, and in one hour have received English, Dutch, French, and abus'd them all; but you see the Fates decreed it otherwise, I am now your Wife.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: The Devil shall be mine as soon; go home to your old Office, keep the Door, and let in ev'ry paultry Knight or Squire, that gives a Guinny and a Kiss for Entrance, who being slighted by your Peevish Lady, falls foul on you, as being loath to lose th' Imagination of Enjoyment, though with her meanest Servants.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Good Bully Sympleton, how like an Ass you look now, I must confess you have such a smart way of Courtship, such taking Charms, such sweet Devices, no Woman can hold out. Wish you much Joy Sir. Gad Drayner let's serenade him with the second part to the same Tune.
sp.l: I had a Miss, a Dainty, Dainty Miss,
Who could at once, Dissemble, Cog, and Kiss;
This Miss I Gad grew weary of the Life,
Jilted Sir Jasper, and became a Wife.
sp.p: How do you like it Bully, Ha?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Come, come Sir, be patient, you are now a Knight Alamode, a Courtier of the Fashion, for scarce one of them but Marry some Debauch'd Lady or other, and count it happiness if but three Nations have enjoy'd her; and this Pasty is of your own Cutting up, and no doubt will prove a Vertuous Wife.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: A Vertuous Devil she may: Pox of the Sex in general, and in particular thee: farewel Wife, farewel Bully; mayst thou Love on, till thou Reelst like a Drunken Dutchman, and in that Humour Commit Adultery with some Gotish Citizen, till the hot Pestilence of Pleasure sink thee into another World.

div.stage: Offers to go, but is hindred by Drayner.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Stay Sir, stay, I have your hand here to confirm a Contract, which I give up to Julia, and here I vow by all those Plagues you heap'd upon her head, to kill you instantly, unless you take her to your Arms.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: Why this to your friend Drayner? Pox you'r a man of Wit, and Merit, and I know have more discretion, then to Bubble your Obliging Friend and Servant.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: I am resolv'd nothing shall stop my fury; take her, or—

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: Pox on ye, come, had I Courage enough to die, I would be hang'd before I'de have a Chamber-maid.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: A Chamber-maid, Ha, Ha, Ha; give me thy hand Sympleton, give you much joy, a Chamber-maid, Ha.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: Well, well Sir, let nothing trouble you, my Chamber-maid may be a Lady as soon as your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Give you much joy, I say no more Bully, but now I hope I may Court my Mistress without the trouble of Poetising, Drinking, or Whoring, Ha, Bully Sympleton.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: You may Sir, but she's Married.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: The Devil she is, to whom?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: A Shepherd Sir, one poor but honest, and such a one as Nature only made equal in Graces to compare with her, won by her prayers and tears; I stole her hence, and gave her to a faithful Shepherd, who was her Conduct to him.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: S'death am I gold by Shepherds? the base Slaves shall die: who was the Principal?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p:
One though unfortunate, may boast himself a Souldier
and a Gentleman, one whom she thought was Dead, the worthy Vinbore.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: A very honest fellow I Gad, and one I love extreamly, though I never saw him; he shall enjoy her, my blessing wait upon him, that is, continual Love, and want of Women Kind, light on him.

div.stage: Enter a Constable▪ and Watchmen.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: There, there are the Murderers, seize on 'em all; if they refuse, knock'em down, we have the Law on our sides.

div.stage: They offer to seize 'em.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Draw Gentlemen, they b●●e the sight of a Sword.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Not I by Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: Not I by Jove; what Draw against a Constable?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: What Brother Constable, are you here?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Keep off Sir, how came you to be my Brother?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: When you were hot upon the search for my Master, this Gentlemans Murderer, I to secure his Person which might casually fall into your hands, and to create a Jest, disguis'd my self into the shape of an Officer, and coming into your Company, I carried you to the Tavern, where both the Murderer and Murther'd stood like Images, and to maintain the Jest, I appear'd as fearful as your Worship, giving the first start at what I knew so well, Sir Symon Credulous in Armor. Discovers himself.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: What Sly, my subtle serving-man?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: The same Sir, born to bring you out of these dangerous troubles.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Was there no Ghost in the Tavern then?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: None I assure you, unless these Gentlemen are Devils.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Oh dishonour to our Office, and stain to this staff of Dignity, seize upon 'em all, I'le teach you to abuse Authority, you are as wicked as Players, who make no more of a Constable, then of a Cobler.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: The Cause you seize us for's so means we scorn to stand against it,— here we all yield our selves, do what you can, or dare. All deliver their Swords.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Nay now you are Civil Gentlemen, and wer't not that I have another Warrant, which is too great to disobey, I'de give you all your Liberties; the King is lost, and 'tis to be suppos'd Murther'd,
upon which I have Order to secure ev'ry suspitious Person▪

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: How the King lost?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: And Murder'd!

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: Oh Horror!

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Nay now we may be hang'd indeed, but sure the King had more wit then to die of his own accord, 'tis mear Treason by Jove.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: It can't be less, therefore Gentlemen till news comes of our Soveraign, this Tavern shall be your Goal, to no worse place I'le carry you.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: I Gad thou art the merriest Constable in Europe; come along Brother Traytors, Madam Sympleton you are a Conspirator too, come along Boys:
sp.l: When sparkish Bacchanalians Traytors turn,
We'l swim through Fire, and in Canary burn.

div.stage: Exeunt. Manet Sly and Drayner.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.l: So now we are Reveng'd, and Profits grow
More great, then e're this Fops has to bestow,
When Profit and Revenge together meet;
Each hour successes Crown'd fall at our feet:
How bright each Motion to that Bliss doth prove!
Revenge once Compass'd, tasts more sweet then Love. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE the Court.
div.stage: Enter the King and Vanlore, leading Heroina, attended by Theocrine Shepherds, and Shepherdesses, at one door; at the other, Zannazarro, Glorianda, and Amasia, all in Mourning, attended by the Kings Guard, Zannazarro kneels, and having kiss'd Heroina's hand, Roses.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: The best of welcomes this sad place affords wait on your Grace's Entertainment.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I thank you Sir, but must first Employ your service in declaring, what these silent Emblems of a sorrow means?

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: Wilt please you Madam, lend your attention to the saddest Story that e're did yet Seicilia's Annals Blot; The Scene draws, and discovers the Picture of the King. Behold great Princess, all but the memory of the living fame of Syracusias Monarch. Heroina swoons.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Help, help the Princess.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.p: Madam, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Oh, Oh, Oh.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: Bear her forth, and give her more Air.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Hold, I am better here; if any thing revive my Spirits, 'twill be this that puts me in mind of my deceased Lord. Why stand you thus amaz'd? Enter Oroandes, Zannazarro, and the rest seem amazed.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: Pardon us Madam; had the united dust of some dead friend, whose memories ne're forgot, visited Earth in his own shape again, our wonder could not have arriv'd unto a higher Pitch. Let me Embrace thee friend.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Stand off, yet farther off,— you know not what you touch; you safer far may grapple with a flame; or in his midnight walks, affront a friend arm'd with full Vials of destructive wrath: the Graves Inhabitants, when folded in Corruption, are not more defil'd then I.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: What tends this Language to?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Destruction, Zannazarro.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.p: How hast thou lost thy Temper Oroandes, prithee look on me friend, am I grown a stranger to thy knowledg?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Leave me Amasia, thou art of kin unto those hollow'd Angels that did once attend my Actions, and must now with them a stranger to thy Oroandes grow.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: You are to me a stranger Sir, yet in your looks something I read, that may concern your absent Prince.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: I do, and would Relate it, but that it hath a sound so full of horror, I tremble to Relate it; yet I must, no other way can lead my Soul out of this wilderness of flesh; he's Murther'd.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: By whom?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: By me, do ve start? 'twas I, 'twas I, that when your blooming hope chear'd with the Sun of Majesty, were grown big with expected favours, did Eclipse the Glorious Light in a Black Cloud of Death; I cut the heart-strings of the Land, and fed the Groaning Land with Blood, whose Purple had bin by an Ancient Stock of Ancestors dy'd into Royalty.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Ingrateful Slave, why are our Swords so slow to Execute the Villain? Offers to Draw.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.p: Oh hold, believe him not, he Raves.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Thou hast but injur'd me Amasia, in staying their just fury.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Oh Brother if this be true, thou hast undone us all.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: True, do not think this any Natural Distemper, that spreads this Malignant Vapour through my Veins, which nought but the Poison of my Guilt Corrupts; yes I have done it Brother, and you are all bound, as you love your Prince, to see't Reveng'd with Torments; here's a Note will when I'm dead, direct you where to find him. Flings Zannazarro a Note. And now I've done my Business on the Earth, I'le give the first stroke to Revenge, and here open a passage for your Swords to Enter. Draws his Sword, and offers to kill himself; is stay'd by the King. What bold hand is that?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: One that here may claim a priviledg. Discovers himself, all kneel by Heroina. Rise thou true Mirror of all Royalty, ne're higher in our favour.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: Our Gracious Soveraign!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Welcome, Oh welcome Royal Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: You are all my much lov'd Subjects, such in whom never was King more Blest; Madam your presence Crowns our Joys, now I stand Exalted in the Zenith of my Fate; who would not pass a Stormy Night, to be thus Courted by a Glorious Day? You all are sharers in my heart, but thou my Love To Heroina. the chief Commandress of that Royal Fort.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: My Joys are now Compleated, and I find a Sea of Pleasure Crowns my Dangers past; what those were, at your leisure I'le Relate.
sp.l: Now Joy and Thanks alike my Brest possess,
Which leads me to a World of Happiness.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hymen shall light us to that World of Joy,
Which once possess'd, shall all our Cares destroy.

sp.speaker: Arratus.
sp.p: I should chide you, but 'tis no time to wear an angry brow, although the Crime was monstrous,, to hier two wicked Slaves to Murder Vanlore, who then lay Leaguer at Ardenna, but by Miracle preserv'd, to save mine and Heroina's Life, for which all he desires, is your free Consent to Marry Theocrine.

div.stage: Vanlore and Theocrine kneels.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: My Lord he has it and I Joy to hear his Life was sav'd to Act 〈◊〉 brave a ●●eed, Rise and receive my Blessing, you are a worthy Son.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: To add a Title to that Honour, I here Create him 〈◊〉 you Oroandes to a Place of greater worth, and nearer to our 〈◊〉, thy Loyal 〈◊〉 merrits it.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Long live Antequam and Heroina, King and Queen of Scicily.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: My Debts are great to all, but must remain in full Arrears until my Off'rings pay'd to fair Heroina give me liberty:
sp.l: Then lull'd in Peace▪ and by this prize set down,
Wee'l find new ways past Victories to Crown.
The mighty Bliss about my Soul doth move
In diff'rent forms, like unknown Joys Above,
B'ing Crown'd at once with Loyalty and Love.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: WHAT strange unkindness doth amongst you Reign,
Sure you will ne're leave off this Damming strein;
You Sans remorse, like Cruel Victors kill;
Both Friend and Foe must suffer by your will,
And all you do is good, though ne're so ill;
Your Native sweetness sure is from you fled,
And all kind Nature is Extinct and Dead;
Like Miss Enjoy'd, you lead us to the Door,
Quite Cloy'd, you thrust us out, and Love no more,
Leave us like her to all Ensuing harms,
And Curse the ill, because you hate her Charms:
By Instigation, or by Precept led,
You that are Wits the Guiddy faction head;
And taught by them, ill Nature and their spight,
Y' Explode what they call wrong, though ne're so right.
Like Massanello's our kind Judges sit,
Cry down the Play, because they hate the Wit;
Damm me sayes one, why so Satyrick here,
What means the Fop to Ramble from his sphere,
And Carp at things, the gravest Poets fear?
Troth 'twas Invention, though he mist the way,
He writ, and hop'd to please as well as they,
But he mistook, and Jaded his poor Muse,
And what he though Jocose, prov'd mere abuse.
The Drudging Scribler quakes within, for fear
You should turn Hectors and dissect him here;
His little frailty sure you can forgive,
And Impudence you know deserves to live;
You may be merciful, though you are Foes,
Since to your Rage at once he did Expose
All he held dear, to Lead you by the Nose.
